results.title: Antigonish
results.creator_credit: Stanley Jackson, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: From places far distant, students come to this quiet Nova Scotia town to study the cooperative movement and to learn skills they can take back to their own countries. At St. Francis Xavier University, Antigonish, this film shows the work of the Coady International Institute.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Stanley Jackson, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Another day in paradise
results.creator_credit: Larry Clark, James Woods, Stephen Chin and Chinese Bookie pictures
results.brief_description: Based on a true story, Larry Clark’s offbeat road movie delves into familiar territory for the always controversial director, that being the search for or absence of a familial or communal maxim. Based on a novel by Eddie Little, “Another day in paradise” follows the misadventures of two young criminal lovers and part-time junkies Bobbie and Rosie (Vincent Kartheiser and Natasha Gregson Wagner) who team up with the more experienced crime couple Mel and Sid (James Woods and Melanie Griffith) to commit a series of robberies across America. Bobbie, coming from a seriously dysfunctional family (with hints of physical abuse from his father), begins to form a strong familial bond with the childless Mel and Sid. The ‘happy families’ scenario begins to come apart however when the crew begin to get more reckless with their crimes, while falling heavier into drug use. Larry Clark (whose past photographic essays on teenagers inform most of his film work), adopts his usual languid style as the camera casually drifts over young bodies, their boredom only slightly elevated by sporadic bursts of violence. In contrast, James Woods gives his familiar intense performance, while Melanie Griffith imbues her role with a unselfconscious charm as the junkie substitute ‘mother’ for this ill-fated family. Cast includes: Lou Diamond Philips, Peter Sarsgaard.

results.title: Anti-government protests in China
results.material_description: Digital screen recording of @TomMackenzieTV's twitter post
results.brief_description: Street protests have broken out in major Chinese cities. Originally sparked by strick Covid lockdowns, protestors have been calling for greater freedom from state control on a number of issues. Police have been observed deleting photos and video of the events from participants’ phones in a vain attempt to limit the spread of information.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

The media is strictly controlled in China through a variety of regulatory guidelines, which include not reporting on pro-democracy movements. Social media and smartphones can sidestep these directives, allowing everyday citizens to record and share their experiences – and organise. Sparked by ongoing Covid lockdowns and a fire that broke out in an apartment building, which authorities couldn’t reach because of Covid infrastructure around the building, mass protests have broken out across China. While demonstrations aren’t uncommon in the country, simultaneous mass uprisings, coordinated on social media, are. Police have been seen deleting footage from participants’ phones, but the vision has already escaped China’s borders and been broadcast on social and traditional media.

As the Wall Street Journal writes, “Twitter Becomes Stage for China Protests Despite Ban by Beijing”, with protestors using Virtual Private Networks (VPNs) to post their videos, as well as reacting quickly before the government’s censorship algorithms catch up. Footage seen in recent days include protestors fighting with authorities in high-rise stairways (embedded below) and medical authorities patrolling daily Covid tests with machine guns. However, without the usual verification methods used by traditional media outlets, it’s hard to be certain of the authenticity of videos. Meanwhile, anti-lockdown activists in other countries have been quick to point out that many countries suppressed anti-lockdown protests.

The uprisings are being likened to the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests. Film of that protest’s most iconic images – showing the lone ‘Tank Man’ standing up against the military – were smuggled out of the country. Today, that smuggling and dissemination is happening over digital networks. Unlike the Tiananmen Square protests, which only happened in Beijing, this recent round of protests are happening around the country.
description_for_label: The media is strictly controlled in China by a variety of regulatory guidelines, including not broadcasting pro-democracy movements. Social media and smartphones can sidestep these directives, allowing everyday citizens to record and share their experiences – and organise. Sparked by ongoing Covid lockdowns, mass protests have broken out across China. While demonstrations aren’t uncommon in the country, simultaneous mass uprisings, coordinated on social media, are. Police have been deleting footage from participants’ phones, but the world has already seen it.

results.title: Annie Leibovitz
results.creator_credit: Rebecca Frayn, Belinda Allen, RM Arts and LWT
results.brief_description: Formulated on the occasion of a major retrospective on the work of renowned photographer Annie Leibovitz at the International Center of Photography, New York, which toured internationally, this documentary explores Leibovitz’s career from the 1960s to the 1990s and discusses a wide range of her most celebrated work during this time. The program features in-depth interviews with Leibovitz herself about her life, career and particular works and features commentary from her colleagues, art critics and her subjects, including commentary from Mick Jagger, Demi Moore, Hunter S. Thompson and the editors of Rolling Stone and Vanity Fair magazines. Liebovitz is filmed at work on various photo shoots with a focus on sequences surrounding her most compelling images such as the 1977 concert tour with the Rolling Stones, her cover photo of Yoko Ono and John Lennon taken shortly before his death in 1980, and the controversial 1993 cover shot of a naked and pregnant Demi Moore. Through such wide ranging material the program traces the progression and turning points of her life and work and the stylistic visions which signify particular points in her career. It provides a thorough survey on and insight into this major photographer, her documentation of American youth culture, politics, celebrity culture and her own professional and personal aims and achievements.

results.title: Antarctica: physical geography
results.creator_credit: Chris McCullough, Stafford Garner and National Geographic Society
results.brief_description: Detailed documentary on the world’s coldest continent, Antarctica. Discusses a variety of topics including the geography and climate of the continent, the marine life it supports, and how this “polar desert” can be viewed as a barometer of earth’s wellbeing, both past and present. Includes archival footage of Australian explorer Douglas Mawson’s expedition to Antarctica in 1912.

results.title: Anne of Green Gables: The Sequel (Captioned)
results.brief_description: Multi-award winning “Anne of Green Gables: the Sequel” continues the charming story of Anne Shirley, now an attractive and high spirited 18 year old teacher at Avonlea, whose life is brimming with romantic dreams, comic mishaps and adventure. Based on three books by Lucy Maud Montgomery: “Anne of Avonlea”, “Anne of the Island”, and “Anne of Windy Poplars”.

results.title: Anne of Green Gables (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Kevin Sullivan, Ian McDougall and Sullivan Films
results.brief_description: Artistically filmed amidst the spectacular scenery of Prince Edward Island, Canada, this award winning movie follows the provocative life drama of Anne Shirley, an endearing orphan, from her struggles as an adolescent to her triumphs as a young woman. Based on the novel “Anne of Green Gables” by Lucy Maud Montgomery, it stars Megan Follows and Colleen Dewhurst.

results.title: Anne Frank remembered
results.creator_credit: Jon Blair, Disney Channel, BBC and Jon Blair Film Company
results.brief_description: Anne Frank has been described as one of the icons of the 20th century with her diary the second most read book of Western non-fiction after the Bible. Narrated by Kenneth Brannagh, with Glenn Close reading excerpts from the famous bestseller, John Blair’s film is effective in placing Anne’s story firmly in its 20th century context. This is not just her life in Holland and her death in a Nazi concentration camp, but the impact the diary has had in the half century since. Suitable for Upper Secondary level student, this packi includes a comprehensive study guide.
